{{Redirect|Rabelais}} {{Use dmy dates|date=May 2011}} {{Infobox writer | name = François Rabelais | image = Francois Rabelais - Portrait.jpg | imagesize = | alt = | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_name = | birth_date = Between 1483 and 1494 | birth_place = [[Chinon]], [[Kingdom of France]] | death_date = 9 April 1553 | death_place = [[Paris]], Kingdom of France | occupation = Writer, physician, humanist | nationality = French | ethnicity = | citizenship = | education = | alma_mater = {{plainlist| *[[University of Poitiers]] *[[University of Montpellier]]}} | period = | genre = | subject = | movement = [[Renaissance humanism]] | notableworks = ''[[Gargantua and Pantagruel]]'' }} '''François Rabelais''' ({{IPAc-en|ˌ|r|æ|b|ə|ˈ|l|eɪ}};[http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/rabelais,+françois "Rabelais, François"]. ''The [[The American Heritage Dictionary of the English Language|American Heritage]] New Dictionary of Cultural Literacy''. {{IPA-fr|fʁɑ̃swa ʁablɛ|lang}}; between 1483 and 1494 – 9 April 1553) was a [[French Renaissance]] writer, physician, [[Renaissance humanist]], monk and [[ancient Greece|Greek]] scholar. He has historically been regarded as a writer of fantasy, satire, the grotesque, bawdy jokes and songs. His best known work is ''[[Gargantua and Pantagruel]]''. Because of his literary power and historical importance, Western literary critics consider him one of the great writers of world literature and among the creators of modern European writing.{{cite book |author=Mihail Mihajlovič Bakhtin|title=Rabelais and His World|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SkswFyhqRIMC&pg=PA1|accessdate=6 January 2013|year=1984|publisher=Indiana University Press|isbn=978-0-253-20341-0|pages=1–2}} His literary legacy is such that today, the word ''Rabelaisian'' has been coined as a descriptive inspired by his work and life. [[Webster's Dictionary|Merriam-Webster]] defines the word as describing someone or something that is "marked by gross robust humor, extravagance of caricature, or bold naturalism".{{cite web|title=Rabelaisian|work=[[Merriam-Webster]]|url=http://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/rabelaisian}} == Biography == No reliable documentation of the place or date of the birth of François Rabelais has survived. While some scholars put the date as early as 1483, he was probably born in November 1494 near [[Chinon]] in the province of [[Touraine]], where his father worked as a lawyer.{{Harvnb|The Rabelais Encyclopedia|p=xiii}}{{cite web |title= Rabelais, François |publisher=The Columbia Encyclopedia, Sixth Edition. 2001–07. |url= http://www.bartleby.com/65/ra/Rabelais.html |accessdate=27 May 2008}} The estate of ''La Devinière'' in [[Seuilly]] in the modern-day [[Indre-et-Loire]], allegedly the writer's birthplace, houses a Rabelais museum. Rabelais became a [[Novitiate|novice]] of the [[Franciscan]] [[Religious order|order]], and later a [[friar]] at [[Fontenay-le-Comte]] in [[Poitou]], where he studied [[Ancient Greek|Greek]] and [[Latin]] as well as science, [[philology]], and law, already becoming known and respected by the humanists of his era, including [[Guillaume Budé]] (1467-1540). Harassed due to the directions of his studies and frustrated with the Franciscan order's ban on the study of Greek (because of [[Erasmus]]' commentary on the Greek version of the ''Gospel of Saint Luke''),{{cite book| last=Boulenger| first=Jacques | title=''"Introduction: Vie de Rabelais" in'' Œuvres complètes de François Rabelais| language=French | year=1978 | publisher=Gallimard (La Bibliothèque de la Pléiade) }}{{rp|11}} Rabelais petitioned [[Pope Clement VII]] (in office 1523-1534) and gained permission to leave the Franciscans and to enter the [[Order of Saint Benedict|Benedictine]] order at [[Maillezais]] in [[Poitou]], where he was more warmly received.{{cite book |last=Febvre|first=Lucien|title=The Problem of Unbelief in the Sixteenth Century, the Religion of Rabelais|year=1982|publisher=Harvard College|isbn= 0-674-70825-3 |pages= 264|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=TIanJUOYnAAC&pg=PA264&lpg=PA264&dq=rabelais+harassed+by+franciscans&source=bl&ots=gEFLgu3fg8&sig=YkBo5KioyJpogTwGUxLMYgRTFqw&hl=en&sa=X&ei=lV2XT7_8KoPI9gT36-25Dg&ved=0CDcQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=rabelais%20harassed%20by%20franciscans&f=false}} [[File:Rabelaismaisonmetz.jpg|thumb|The house of François Rabelais in [[Metz]]]] Later he left the monastery to study medicine at the [[University of Poitiers]] and at the [[University of Montpellier]]. In 1532 he moved to [[Lyon]], one of the intellectual centres of the Renaissance, and in 1534 began working as a doctor at the [[Hôtel-Dieu de Lyon]] (hospital), for which he earned 40 ''livres'' a year. During his time in Lyon, he edited Latin works for the printer [[Sebastian Gryphius]], became friends with [[Étienne Dolet]], and worked up the nerve to write to Erasmus. Gryphius published his translations of [[Hippocrates]], [[Galen]] and Giovanni Mainardi. As a physician, he used his spare time to write and publish humorous pamphlets critical of established authority and preoccupied with the educational and monastic mores of the time.{{rp|13-15}} In 1532, under the pseudonym '''Alcofribas Nasier''' (an [[anagram]] of François Rabelais), he published his first book, ''Pantagruel King of the Dipsodes'', the first of his [[Gargantua and Pantagruel|''Gargantua'' series]]. The idea of basing an allegory on the lives of giants came to Rabelais from the folklore legend of ''les Grandes chroniques du grand et énorme géant Gargantua'', which were sold as popular literature at the time in the form of inexpensive pamphlets by colporters and at the fairs of Lyon.{{rp|13}} Pantagruelisme is an "eat, drink and be merry" philosophy, which led his books into disfavor with the church, simultaneously brought them popular success and the admiration of later critics for their focus on the body. This first book, critical of the existing monastic and educational system, contains the first known occurrence in French of the words [[Encyclopedia | ''encyclopédie'']], [[Kaballah | ''caballe'']], ''progrès'' and [[Utopia|''utopie'']] among others.{{cite article| last=Huchon| first=Mireille | title="Pantagruelistes et mercuriens lyonnais" in'' Lyon et l'illustration de la langue française à la Renaissance''| language=French | year=2003 | page=405 | publisher=ENS Éditions }}Original context ([https://fr.wikisource.org/wiki/Pantagruel/%C3%89dition_Marty-Laveaux,_1868/Chapitre_20 fr] / [https://books.google.fr/books?id=Hl6PtUdIFawC&pg=PA201&lpg=PA201&dq=THAUMASTE+GOT+UP&source=bl&ots=XRES6tWWRv&sig=nmIgIfsPnCN8cn1SboCxQ4i87Y8&hl=en&sa=X&ved=2ahUKEwiL8LLLodzeAhWwxoUKHSSpAkMQ6AEwAHoECAYQAQ#v=onepage&q=THAUMASTE%20GOT%20UP&f=false en]) Despite the book's popularity, both it and the subsequent [[prequel]] book (1534) about the life and exploits of Pantagruel's father Gargantua were condemned by the academics at the [[Collège de Sorbonne|Sorbonne]], in particular [[Guillaume Postel]] in 1543, {{cite book|author=Lucien Febvre|title=Le Problème de l'incroyance au XVIe siècle|date=1942|publisher=Albin Michel}}{{rp|111-115, 128-132}} for their unorthodox ideas and by the [[Roman Catholic Church]] for their derision of certain religious practices. Rabelais taught medicine at Montpellier in 1534 and again in 1539. In 1537, Rabelais gave an anatomy lesson at Lyon's Hôtel-Dieu using the corpse of a hanged man.{{rp|xvii}} In June 1543 Rabelais became a [[Master of Requests (France)|Master of Requests]].{{cite journal|last1=Marichal|first1=Robert|title=Rabelais fût il Maître des Requêtes?|journal=Bibliothèque d'Humanisme et Renaissance|date=1948|volume=10|pages=169–178, at p. 169.|jstor=20673434|registration=yes }} Between 1545 and 1547 François Rabelais lived in [[Metz]], then a [[free imperial city]] and a republic, to escape the condemnation by the [[University of Paris]]. In 1547, he became [[curate]] of [[Saint-Christophe-du-Jambet]] in [[Maine (province)|Maine]] and of [[Meudon]] near Paris, from which he resigned in January 1553 before his death in Paris in April 1553.{{rp|xx-xxi}} There aren't many speaking roles for women in the Rabelaisian adventures, not even in ''[[Gargantua and Pantagruel#The Third Book|Le Tiers Livre]]'' where the recurrent theme is whether Panurge should marry or not. Pantagruel's mother, for example, dies in childbirth; Gargantua's mother (Gargamelle) fades from the story as soon as the newborn giant has climbed out her ear into life. This book was published under Rabelais' own name in 1546 and dedicated to King Francis I's sister [[Marguerite of Navarre]], and was also banned by the Sorbonne. It revisited discussions he had had while working as a secretary to Geoffroy d'Estissac earlier in Poitiers, and with his patron Marguerite de Navarre shortly before she wrote the [[Heptameron]]{{cite journal|title=Rabelais and Marguerite de Navarre on Sixteenth-Century Views of Clandestine Marriage | author = Cathleen M. Bauschatz | journal = Sixteenth Century Journal | volume = 34 | issue = 2 | date = 2003| url = https://www.jstor.org/stable/20061415 | doi = 10.2307/20061415 }} [[The Woman Question|''la querelle des femmes'']] was a lively subject of debate in intellectual circles at the time.{{rp|xix}} With support from members of the prominent [[du Bellay family]], Rabelais received approval from [[Francis I of France|King Francis I]] to continue to publish his collection. However, after the king's death in 1547, the academic élite frowned upon Rabelais, and the French [[Parlement]] suspended the sale of his fourth book (''[[Gargantua and Pantagruel#The Fourth Book|Le Quart Livre]]'') published in 1552.{{rp|xx}}{{Cite journal|last=Lefranc|first=Abel|date=1929|title=Rabelais, la Sorbonne et le Parlement en 1552 (partie 1)|url=http://www.persee.fr/doc/crai_0065-0536_1929_num_73_4_75794|journal=Comptes rendus des séances de l'Académie des Inscriptions et Belles-Lettres|volume=73|pages=276|via=}} Rabelais traveled frequently to Rome with his friend Cardinal [[Jean du Bellay]], and lived for a short time in [[Turin]] (1540- ) as part of the household of du Bellay's brother, [[Guillaume du Bellay|Guillaume]], while king [[Francis I of France|François I]] was his patron. Rabelais spent some time in hiding, under periodic threat of being condemned of [[heresy]] depending upon the health of his various protectors. Only the protection of du Bellay saved Rabelais after the condemnation of his novel by the [[Collège de Sorbonne|Sorbonne]].{{rp|xix-xx}} == ''Gargantua and Pantagruel'' == {{Main article|Gargantua and Pantagruel}} [[File:Gustave Dore X.jpg|thumb|Illustration for ''Gargantua and Pantagruel'' by [[Gustave Doré]].]] [[File:Gustave Dore XII.jpg|thumb|Illustration for ''Gargantua and Pantagruel'' by Gustave Doré.]] ''Gargantua and Pantagruel'' relates the adventures Gargantua and his son Pantagruel. The tales are adventurous and erudite, festive and gross, toxic ecumenical and rarely -- if ever -- solemn for long. The first book, chronologically, was Pantagruel and the Gargantua mentioned in the Prologue refers not to Rabelais' own work but to storybooks that were being sold at the Lyon fairs in the early 1530s.{{rp|297, 300}} In the first chapter of the earliest book, Pantagruel's lineage is listed back 60 generations to a giant named Chalbroth. The narrator dismisses the skeptics of the time—who would have thought a giant far too large for [[Noah's Ark]]—stating that Hurtaly (the giant reigning during the flood and a great fan of soup) simply rode the Ark like a kid on a rocking horse, or like a fat Swiss guy on a canon.{{rp|508-514}} In the Prologue to ''Gargantua'' the narrator addresses : "Most illustrious drinkers, and ''you'' the most precious pox-ridden{{mdash}}for to ''you'' and ''you'' alone are my writings dedicated ..." before turning to Plato's ''[[Symposium_(Plato)|Banquet]]''.{{rp|50}} An unprecedented syphilis epidemic had raged through Europe for over 30 years when the book was published,{{cite web|author = James Marshall | title = Rabelais on Syphilis | journal = Nature | doi= 10.1038/162118a0 | url = https://www.nature.com/articles/162118a0.pdf | date = July 7, 1948 | access-date = November 20, 2018 }} even the king of France was reputed to have been infected. Etion was the first giant in Pantagruel's list of ancestors to suffer from the disease.{{rp|510}} Although most chapters are humorous, wildly fantastic and frequently absurd, a few relatively serious passages have become famous for expressing humanistic ideals of the time. In particular, the chapters on Gargantua's boyhood and Gargantua's paternal letter to Pantagruel{{cite book|last=Rabelais|first=François|title=The Histories of Gargantua and Pantagruel|translator=J. M. Cohen|location=Harmondsworth|publisher=Penguin|series=Penguin Classics|year=1955}}{{rp|192-6}} present a quite detailed vision of education. ===''Thélème''=== {{See also|Thelema}} In the first book, M. Alcofribas narrates the Abbey of Thélème, built by the giant Gargantua. It differs remarkably from the monastic norm, as the abbey is open to both monks and nuns, has a swimming pool, maid service, and no clocks in sight. Only the good-looking are permitted to enter.{{cite book | author1 = François Rabelais | author2 = Guy Demerson | author3 = Geneviève Demerson | title = Rabelais: Œuvres complètes | date = 1995 | publisher = Seuil}}{{rp|268-9}} The inscription on the gate to the abbey first sets out who is unwelcome: hypocrites, bigots, the pox-ridden, Gothz, Magothz, the straw-chewing law clerks, usurious grinches, old or officious judges, and burners of heretics.{{rp|272}} When the members are defined positively, the text becomes more inviting:
::::Honour, praise, distraction ::::Herein lies subtraction ::::in the tuning up of joy. ::::To healthy bodies so employed ::::Do pass on this reaction: ::::Honour, praise, distraction{{rp|274}}
[[File:RabelaisPentagruelTitlepage1571.jpg|thumb|250px|Titlepage of a 1571 edition containing the last three books of Pantagruel: ''Le Tiers Livre des Faits & Dits Heroïques du Bon Pantagruel'' (The Third Book of the True and Reputed Heroic Deeds of the Noble Pantagruel)]] The Thélèmites in the abbey live according to a single rule: DO WHAT YOU WANT. == Use of language == The French Renaissance was a time of linguistic contact and debate. The first book of French, rather than Latin, grammar was published in 1530,{{cite web|url=http://ctlf.ens-lyon.fr/n_fiche.asp?num=2202 | title = notice John Palsgrave | author1 = Jacques Julien | author2 = Susan Baddely | date = April 2016 | language = fr |publisher=CTLF|access-date=November 17, 2018}} followed nine years later by the language's first dictionary.{{cite book | url = https://gallica.bnf.fr/ark:/12148/bpt6k505878 | title = Dictionnaire francois latin contenant les motz et manières de parler francois, tournez en latin | date = 1539 | publisher = Robert Estienne | year = 1539 | location = Paris | language = fr | pages=}} Spelling was far less codified back then. Rabelais, as an educated reader of the day, preferred [[etymological]] spelling which preserved words' histories to more phonetic spellings which would wash them away. Rabelais' use of Latin, Greek, regional and dialectal terms, creative [[claque | calquing]], [[Gloss_(annotation) | gloss]], [[neologism]] and mis-translation was the fruit of the printing press having been invented less than a hundred years earlier. A doctor by trade, Rabelais was a prolific reader, and wrote a great deal about bodies and all they excrete or ingest. His works are filled with multilingual, often sexual, puns, absurd creatures, bawdy songs and lists. Words and metaphors from Rabelais abound in modern French and some words, as mentioned above, have even found their way into English, through [[Thomas Urquhart]]'s 1693 translation. ==Views on Rabelais== Most scholars today agree that the French author wrote from a perspective of [[Christian humanism]].{{Harvnb|Bowen|1998}} This has not always been the case. [[Abel Lefranc]], in his 1922 introduction to ''Pantagruel'', depicted Rabelais as a militant anti-Christian atheist.Davis, Natalie Zemon. "Beyond Babel" in Davis & Hampton, "Rabelais and His Critics". ''Occasional Papers Series'', University of California Press. [[M. A. Screech]], like Lucien Febvre before him,{{rp|329-360}} describes Rabelais as an [[Erasmus|Erasmian]].{{Harvnb|Screech|1979|p=14}} Rabelais was Roman Catholic. Timothy Hampton writes that "to a degree unequaled by the case of any other writer from the European Renaissance, the reception of Rabelais's work has involved dispute, critical disagreement, and ... scholarly wrangling ..."Hampton, Timothy. "Language and Identities" in Davis & Hampton, "Rabelais and His Critics". ''Occasional Papers Series'', University of California Press. But at present, "whatever controversy still surrounds Rabelais studies can be found above all in the application of feminist theories to Rabelais criticism".{{cite book | author = Bruno Braunrot |chapter=Critical Theory | title = The Rabelais Encyclopedia | page= 45 | url = https://books.google.fr/books?id=RwjWrTd5la4C&pg=PA45&dq=Rabelais+seemingly+misogynous&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjftsz83N3eAhULfxoKHTprAKgQ6AEILDAA#v=onepage&q=Rabelais%20seemingly%20misogynous&f=false}} Citing [[Jean de La Bruyère]], the Catholic Encyclopedia of 1911 wrote of Rabelais as:
... a revolutionary who attacked all the past, Scholasticism, the monks; his religion is scarcely more than that of a spiritually-minded pagan. Less bold in political matters, he cared little for liberty; his ideal was a tyrant who loves peace. [...] His vocabulary is rich and picturesque, but licentious and filthy. In short, as La Bruyère says: "His book is a riddle which may be considered inexplicable. Where it is bad, it is beyond the worst; it has the charm of the rabble; where it is good it is excellent and exquisite; it may be the daintiest of dishes." As a whole it exercises a baneful influence.{{cite web | author = Georges Bertrin | title = The Catholic Encyclopedia: François Rabelais | location = New York | publisher = Robert Appleton Company | date = 1911 | access-date = 25 November 2018 |url = http://www.newadvent.org/cathen/12619b.htm }}
==In literature== {{French literature sidebar}} In his novel ''[[The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman|Tristram Shandy]]'', [[Laurence Sterne]] quotes extensively from Rabelais.{{cite book|last1=Saintsbury|first1=George|title=Tristram Shandy|date=1912|publisher=JM Dent|location=London|page=xx}} [[Alfred Jarry]] performed, from memory, hymns of Rabelais at [[Symbolist]] [[Rachilde]]'s Tuesday [[salon (gathering)|salons]]. Jarry worked for years on an unfinished [[libretto]] for an opera by Claude Terrasse based on Pantagruel.{{cite book |last=Fisher |first=Ben |title=The Pataphysician's Library: An Exploration of Alfred Jarry's Livres Pairs |publisher=Liverpool University Press |year=2000 |isbn=9780853239260 |pages=95–98}} [[Anatole France]] lectured on him in Argentina. [[John Cowper Powys]], [[D. B. Wyndham-Lewis]], and [[Lucien Febvre]] (one of the founders of the French historical school ''[[Annales School|Annales]]''), all wrote books about him. [[Mikhail Bakhtin]], a Russian philosopher and critic, derived his concepts of the [[carnivalesque]] and [[grotesque body]] from the world of Rabelais. He points to the historical loss of communal spirit after the Medieval period and speaks of carnival laughter as an "expression of social consciousness".{{rp|92}} [[George Orwell]] was not an admirer of Rabelais. Writing in 1940, he called him "an exceptionally perverse, morbid writer, a case for psychoanalysis".{{citation|title=Review of ''Nailcruncher'' |first= Albert |last= Cohen| work= The Collected Essays, Journalism and Letters of George Orwell'', Vol. 2}} [[Milan Kundera]], in a 2007 article in ''[[The New Yorker]]'', commented on a list of the most notable works of French literature, noting with surprise and indignation that Rabelais was placed behind [[Charles de Gaulle]]'s war memoirs, and was denied the "aura of a founding figure! Yet in the eyes of nearly every great novelist of our time he is, along with [[Miguel de Cervantes|Cervantes]], the founder of an entire art, the art of the novel".{{cite news|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2007/01/08/die-weltliteratur |title=Die Weltliteratur: European novelists and modernism |first=Milan |last=Kundera |date=8 January 2007 |accessdate=10 November 2017 |newspaper=[[The New Yorker]]}} Rabelais is treated as a pivotal figure in [[Kenzaburō Ōe]]'s acceptance speech for the [[Nobel Prize in Literature]] in 1994.[http://nobelprize.org/nobel_prizes/literature/laureates/1994/oe-lecture.html Ōe lecture], NobelPrize.org, 1994. ==Honours, tributes and legacy== [[File:Meudon Rabelais-parc.JPG|upright|right|thumb|Bust of Rabelais in [[Meudon]], where he served as Curé]] [[File:Rabelaisjdpmontp.JPG|upright|thumb|right|Monument to Rabelais at [[Montpellier]]'s Jardin des Plantes]] * The public university in [[Tours, France]] is named [[Université François Rabelais]]. * [[Honoré de Balzac]] was inspired by the works of Rabelais to write [[:fr:Les Cent Contes drolatiques|Les Cent Contes Drolatiques]] (The Hundred Humorous Tales). Balzac also pays homage to Rabelais by quoting him in more than twenty novels and the short stories of [[La Comédie humaine]] (The Human Comedy). Michel Brix wrote of Balzac that he "is obviously a son or grandson of Rabelais... He has never hidden his admiration for the author of [[:fr:Gargantua|Gargantua]] that he cites in [[Le Cousin Pons]] as "the greatest mind of modern humanity".[[:fr:Bibliothèque de la Pleiade|Bibliothèque de la Pleiade]], 1977, t.VII, p.587Michel Brix,''Balzac and the Legacy of Rabelais, PUF, 2002–2005, vol. 102, p.838 In his story of ''Zéro, Conte Fantastique'' published in [[:fr:La Silhouette|La Silhouette]] on 3 October 1830, Balzac even adopted Rabelais's pseudonym (''Alcofribas''){{cite web | title = Litérature fantastique > Honoré de Balzac | publisher = Le Visage Vert | author = Xavier Legrand-Ferronnière | url=http://www.levisagevert.com/bibliographie-auteurs/auteurs-b/auteurs-b/b0027.html}}. * Rabelais also left a tradition at the [[University of Montpellier|University of Montpellier's Faculty of Medicine]]: no graduating medic can undergo a convocation without taking an oath under ''Rabelais's robe''. Further tributes are paid to him in other traditions of the university, such as its ''[[faluche]]'', a distinctive student headcap styled in his honour with four bands of colour emanating from its centre. * [[5666 Rabelais|Asteroid '5666 Rabelais']] was named in honor of François Rabelais in 1982.{{Cite book |last=Schmadel |first=Lutz D.|author2=International Astronomical Union |title=Dictionary of minor planet names |year=2003 |publisher=Springer-Verlag |location=Berlin; New York |isbn=978-3-540-00238-3 |page=480 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=KWrB1jPCa8AC&pg=PA480|accessdate=9 September 2011}} * In [[J. M. G. Le Clézio|Jean-Marie Gustave Le Clézio's]] 2008 [[Nobel Prize in Literature|Nobel Prize]] [[Nobel Prize#Ceremony|lecture]], Le Clézio referred to Rabelais as "the greatest writer in the French language". * In France the moment at a restaurant when the waiter presents the bill is still sometimes called ''le quart d'heure de Rabelais'', in memory of a famous trick Rabelais used to get out of paying a tavern bill when he had no money.Brillat-Savarin, Anthelme, ''La Physiologie du Gout'', Meditiation 28. == Works == * [[Gargantua and Pantagruel]], a series of four or five books including: ** ''Pantagruel'' (1532) ** ''La vie très horrifique du grand Gargantua'', usually called ''Gargantua'' (1534) ** ''Le Tiers Livre'' ("The third book", 1546) ** ''Le Quart Livre'' ("The fourth book", 1552) ** ''Le Cinquiesme Livre'' (a fifth book, whose authorship is contested) ==See also== * [[Thomas Urquhart]] ==References== '''Notes''' {{Reflist|35em}} '''Bibliography''' *Auden, W.H.; Kronenberger, Louis (1966), ''The Viking Book of Aphorisms'', New York: Viking Press * Bakhtin, Mihail, Tapani Laine, Paula Nieminen, and Erkki Salo. ''François Rabelais: Keskiajan Ja Renessanssin Nauru.'' Helsinki: Like, 1968. * Bakhtin, M. M. [1941, 1965] ''Rabelais and His World''. Trans. Hélène Iswolsky. Bloomington: Indiana University Press, 1993 * Bodemer, Brett: "[http://works.bepress.com/bbodemer/1/ Pantagruel's Seventh Chapter:The Title as Suspect Codpiece]." * {{cite book | last = Bowen| first = Barbara C. | title = Enter Rabelais, Laughing |publisher=Vanderbilt University Press |year=1998 | isbn = 0-8265-1306-9| ref = harv}} * {{cite book |last=Brahms |first=William B. |title= Last Words of Notable People: Final Words of More than 3500 Noteworthy People Throughout History |publisher=Reference Desk Press |year=2010 |location=Haddonfield, NJ |isbn =978-0-9765325-2-1}} * Del Campo, Gerald. ''[https://web.archive.org/web/20061205024236/http://thelemicknights.org/ootmc/rabelais/rabelais.html Rabelais: The First Thelemite]''. The Order of Thelemic Knights. * Dixon, J.E.G. & John L. Dawson. ''Concordance des Oeuvres de François Rabelais.'' Geneva: Librairie Droz, 1992. * Febvre, Lucien. Gottlieb, Beatrice trans. ''The Problem of Unbelief in the Sixteenth Century: The Religion of Rabelais'' (Cambridge: Harvard University Press, 1982). * Langer, Ullrich, "Charity and the Singular: The Object of Love in Rabelais," in: ''Nominalism and Literary Discourse'', ed. Hugo Keiper, [[Christoph Bode]], and Richard Utz (Amsterdam: Rodopi, 1997), pp. 217–26. * Lee, Jae Num. "Scatology in Continental Satirical Writings from Aristophanes to Rabelais" and "English Scatological Writings from Skelton to Pope." Swift and Scatological Satire. Albuquerque: U of New Mexico P, 1971. 7–22; 23–53. * {{cite book |last=Screech |first=M.A. |title= Rabelais |publisher=Duckworth |year=1979 |location=London |isbn =0-7156-1660-9}} == External links == {{Sister project links|author=yes|commonscat=yes|b=no|d=Q131018|n=no|v=no|wikt=no}} * {{Gutenberg author |id=Rabelais,+François | name=François Rabelais}} * {{Internet Archive author |sname=François Rabelais |sopt=w}} * {{Librivox author | id=1151}} * [[Project Gutenberg]] e-text of ''[http://onlinebooks.library.upenn.edu/webbin/gutbook/lookup?num=1200 Gargantua and Pantagruel]'' * Association de Bibliophiles Universels e-text of ''[http://abu.cnam.fr/BIB/auteurs/rabelaisf.html Gargantua]'' in French * [http://www.rabelais.nl/ A Dutch website about Rabelais] * [https://web.archive.org/web/20100111041744/http://www.renaissance-france.org/rabelais/pages/pagrablais2.html Rabelais et la Renaissance], sur le [https://web.archive.org/web/20100110055916/http://www.renaissance-france.org/ Portail de la Renaissance française] (French) * [http://www.musee-rabelais.fr/ François Rabelais Museum on the Internet] (French) * Henry Émile Chevalier, [http://www.bmlisieux.com/curiosa/rabelais.htm ''Rabelais and his editors''], 1868 (French). {{Authority control}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Rabelais, Francois}} [[Category:François Rabelais| ]] [[Category:15th-century births]] [[Category:1553 deaths]] [[Category:People from Indre-et-Loire]] [[Category:University of Poitiers alumni]] [[Category:University of Montpellier alumni]] [[Category:16th-century French physicians]] [[Category:16th-century French writers]] [[Category:Writers from Centre-Val de Loire]] [[Category:16th-century French novelists]] [[Category:Roman Catholic writers]] [[Category:French Benedictines]] [[Category:French Franciscans]] [[Category:French Roman Catholics]] [[Category:French Renaissance]] [[Category:Thelema]] [[Category:French male novelists]] [[Category:French male poets]] [[Category:French medical writers]]

revision.comment: /* Hesiod's primordial genealogy */ adding cyclopses into the list of children of Gaia and Uranus; Aphrodite wasn't a child of Gaia but rather arose from the castration of Uranus
revision.text:
{{Refimprove|date=June 2009}} {{Greek myth (primordial)}} In [[Greek mythology]], the '''primordial deities''' are the first gods and goddesses born from the void of [[Chaos (mythology)|Chaos]]. In [[Orphism (religion)|Orphic tradition]], they are born from [[Chronos]] and [[Ananke (mythology)|Ananke]]. [[Hesiod]]'s first (after Chaos) are [[Gaia (mythology)|Gaia]], [[Tartarus]], [[Eros]], [[Erebus]] and [[Nyx]]. The primordial deities [[Gaia]] and [[Uranus (mythology)|Uranus]] give birth to the [[Titan (mythology)|Titans]], the [[Cyclops|Cyclopses]] and from the castration of Uranus, [[Aphrodite]]. The Titans [[Cronus]] and [[Rhea (mythology)|Rhea]] give birth to [[Zeus]], [[Poseidon]], [[Hades]], [[Hestia]], [[Hera]] and [[Demeter]] who [[Titanomachy|overthrow]] the Titans. The warring of the gods ends with the reign of [[Zeus]]. ==Hesiod's primordial genealogy== [[Hesiod]]'s ''[[Theogony]]'' (c. 700 BC) tells the story of the genesis of the gods. After invoking the [[Muse]]s (II.1-116), he tells of the generation of the first four primordial deities:
"'''First Chaos''' came to be, but next... '''Earth'''... and dim '''Tartarus''' in the depth of the... Earth, and '''Eros'''..."{{Cite web|title = The Theogony of Hesiod|url = http://www.sacred-texts.com/cla/hesiod/theogony.htm|website = www.sacred-texts.com|access-date = 2016-01-21}}
According to Hesiod, the next primordial gods that come to be are: * [[Erebus|Darkness]] and [[Nyx|Night]] (born of [[Chaos (cosmogony)|Chaos]]); * [[Aether (mythology)|Light]] and [[Hemera|Day]] (born of [[Nyx|Night]] and [[Erebus|Darkness]]); * [[Uranus (mythology)|Heaven]] and [[Pontus (mythology)|Ocean]] (virginally born of Earth) === Genealogical tree === * [[Chaos (mythology)|Chaos]] (Void) * [[Gaia (mythology)|Gaia]] (Earth) (female) * [[Ouranos (mythology)|Uranus]] (Sky) (male) * [[Ourea]] (Mountains) (male) * [[Pontus (mythology)|Pontus]] (Sea) (male) * [[Tartarus]] (Underworld) (male) * [[Erebus]] (Darkness) (male) * [[Nyx]] (Night) (female) * [[Aether (mythology)|Aether]] (Light) (male) * [[Hemera]] (Day) (female) * [[Eros]] (Love) (male) (the son of [[Aphrodite]] and [[Ares]] in later myths) ===Other sources=== * [[Achlys]] (Misery) (female) * [[Physis]] (Nature) (female) * [[Ananke (mythology)|Ananke]] (Compulsion) (female) * [[Chronos]] (Time) (male) * [[Aion (deity)|Aion]] (Eternity) (male) * [[Himeros]] (Tension) (male) * [[Phanes (mythology)|Phanes]] (Procreation) (male) * [[Nesoi (mythology)|Nesoi]] (Islands) (female) * [[Thalassa (mythology)|Thalassa]] (Sea) (female) * [[Ophion]] (Life) (male) * [[Moirai]] (Fate) (female) * [[Moros]] (Doom) (male) ==Non-Hesiodic theogonies == The [[Ancient Greece|ancient Greeks]] entertained different versions of the origin of [[Chaos (cosmogony)|primordial deities]]. Some of these stories were possibly inherited from the pre-Greek Aegean cultures.{{Cite book|edition = 2|title = The Politics of Olympus: Form and Meaning in the Major Homeric Hymns|url = https://www.amazon.com/The-Politics-Olympus-Meaning-BCPaperbacks/dp/1853996920|publisher = Bristol Classical Press|date = 2006-05-26|location = London|isbn = 9781853996924|first = Jenny Strauss|last = Clay|page = 9}} ===Homeric primordial theogony=== The ''[[Iliad]]'', an [[epic poem]] attributed to [[Homer]] about the [[Trojan War]] (an oral tradition of 700 or 600 BC), states that [[Oceanus]] (and possibly [[Tethys (mythology)|Tethys]], too) is the parent of all the deities.Homer, ''Iliad'' (Book 14) === Other Greek theogonies === * [[Alcman]] (fl. 7th century BC) made the water-nymph [[Thetis]] the first goddess, producing ''poros'' (path), ''tekmor'' (marker) and ''skotos'' (darkness) on the pathless, featureless void. * [[Orpheus|Orphic]] poetry (c. 530 BC) made [[Nyx]] the first principle, ''Night'', and her offspring were many. Also, in the Orphic tradition, [[Phanes (mythology)|Phanes]] (a mystic Orphic deity of light and procreation, sometimes identified with the Elder Eros) is the original ruler of the universe, who hatched from the cosmic egg.[http://www.theoi.com/Protogenos/Phanes.html Phanes] * [[Aristophanes]] (c. 446 BC – c. 386 BC) wrote in his ''Birds'', that Nyx is the first deity also, and that she produced Eros from an egg. === Philosophical theogonies === Philosophers of [[Classical Greece]] also constructed their own [[cosmology#Metaphysical cosmology|metaphysical cosmogonies]], with their own primordial deities: * [[Pherecydes of Syros]] (c. 600 – c. 550 BC) made Chronos (time) the first deity in his ''Heptamychia''. * [[Empedocles]] (c. 490 – 430 BC) wrote that [[Philotes (mythology)|Philotes]] ("Love") and [[Neikea|Neikos]] ("Hate") were the first principles, who wove the universe out of the [[Classical element|four elements]] with their powers of love and strife. * [[Plato]] (c. 428/427 – 348/347 BC) introduced (in ''Timaeus'') the concept of the [[demiurge]], who had modeled the universe on the [[Idea]]s. == Interpretation of primordial deities == Scholars dispute the meaning of the primordial deities in the poems of Homer and Hesiod.{{Cite book|title = Greek Mythology and Poetics|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=GOO5Z7wqZS0C|publisher = Cornell University Press|date = 1992-01-01|isbn = 0801480485|first = Gregory|last = Nagy}} Since the primordials give birth to the Titans, and the Titans give birth to the Olympians, one way of interpreting the primordial gods is as the deepest and most fundamental nature of the cosmos. For example, [[Jenny Strauss Clay]] argues that Homer's poetic vision centers on the reign of Zeus, but that Hesiod's vision of the primordials put Zeus and the Olympians in context.{{Cite book|edition = 2|title = The Politics of Olympus: Form and Meaning in the Major Homeric Hymns|url = https://www.amazon.com/The-Politics-Olympus-Meaning-BCPaperbacks/dp/1853996920|publisher = Bristol Classical Press|date = 2006-05-26|location = London|isbn = 9781853996924|first = Jenny Strauss|last = Clay|page = 9}} Likewise, Vernant argues that the Olympic pantheon is a "system of classification, a particular way of ordering and conceptualizing the universe by distinguishing within it various types of powers and forces."{{Cite book|title = Myth and Society in Ancient Greece|url = https://books.google.com/books?id=DWIbAAAAYAAJ|publisher = Harvester Press|date = 1980-01-01|isbn = 9780855279837|first = Jean Pierre|last = Vernant}} But even before the Olympic pantheon were the Titans and primordial gods. Homer alludes to a more tumultuous past before Zeus was the undisputed King and Father.{{Cite web|title = The Internet Classics Archive {{!}} The Iliad by Homer|url = http://classics.mit.edu/Homer/iliad.html|website = classics.mit.edu|access-date = 2016-01-21|pages = Book I (396–406); Book VIII (477–83)}} Mitchell Miller argues that the first four primordial deities arise in a highly significant relationship. He argues that Chaos represents ''differentiation'', since Chaos differentiates (separates, divides) Tartarus and Earth.{{Cite web|title = ‘First of all’: On the Semantics and Ethics of Hesiod’s Cosmogony - Mitchell Miller - Ancient Philosophy (Philosophy Documentation Center)|url = https://www.pdcnet.org//pdc/bvdb.nsf/purchase?openform&fp=ancientphil&id=ancientphil_2001_0021_0002_0251_0276&onlyautologin=true|website = www.pdcnet.org|access-date = 2016-01-21}} Even though Chaos is "first of all" for Hesiod, Miller argues that Tartarus represents the primacy of the ''undifferentiated,'' or the [[Apeiron (cosmology)|unlimited]]. Since undifferentiation is unthinkable, Chaos is the "first of all" in that he is the first ''thinkable'' being. In this way, Chaos (the principle of division) is the natural opposite of Eros (the principle of unification). Earth (light, day, waking, life) is the natural opposite of Tartarus (darkness, night, sleep, death). These four are the parents of all the other Titans. ==See also== {{Portal|Greek mythology}} * [[Bibliotheca (Pseudo-Apollodorus)]] * ''[[Ex nihilo]]'' ==References== {{Reflist|35em}} ==External links== * [http://www.theoi.com/greek-mythology/primeval-gods.html Theoi Project – Protogenoi] * [http://www.theoi.com/Tree1.html Theo Project – Protogenoi Family Tree] * [http://www.timelessmyths.com/classical/primeval.html Greek Primeval Deities] {{Greek mythology (deities)}} {{Greek religion}} [[Category:Greek deities]] [[Category:Ancient Greek religion]] [[Category:Mythology-related lists]]

revision.comment: Removing link(s): [[Wikipedia:Articles for deletion/Hinduism in Latvia]] closed as delete ([[WP:XFDC|XFDcloser]])
Reverted [[WP:AGF|good faith]] edits by [[Special:Contributions/120.16.86.41|120.16.86.41]] ([[User talk:120.16.86.41|talk]]): Rmv unsourced and POV addition. ([[WP:TW|TW]])
revision.text:
{{Distinguish|History of the Seventh-day Adventist Church}} {{Seventh-day Adventism}} '''Historic Adventism''' is an informal designation for conservative individuals and organizations affiliated with the [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]] who seek to preserve certain traditional beliefs and practices of the church. They feel that the church leadership has shifted or departed from key doctrinal "pillars" ever since the middle of the 20th century. Specifically, they point to the publication in 1957 of a book entitled ''[[Seventh-day Adventists Answer Questions on Doctrine]]''; which they feel undermines historic Adventist theology in favor of theology more compatible with [[evangelicalism]].<ref name="Corson">{{cite journal | last = Corson | first = Ron | authorlink = | title = Progressive and Traditional Adventists Examined | journal = [[Adventist Today]] | volume = 10 | issue = 6 | pages = <!-- use en-dash "–", if at all --> | publisher = Adventist Today Foundation | location = [[Loma Linda, California|Loma Linda]], [[California|CA]] | issn = 1079-5499 |date=November 2002 | url = http://www.atoday.com/issue_pdf.php?pdf=2002-06.pdf | doi = | id = | accessdate = 2007-11-20 }}</ref> Historic Adventism has been erroneously applied by some to any Adventists that adhere to the teachings of the church as reflected in the church's [[28 Fundamental Beliefs|fundamental beliefs]] such as the Sabbath or the Spirit of Prophecy. They misapply those who hold to mainstream traditional Adventist beliefs as synonymous with Historic Adventist.<ref name="Corson"/>
Historic Adventists have tended to promote their message through [[Independent ministries of the Seventh-day Adventist Church|independent ministries]], some of which have had a strained relationship with the official church.<ref>"[[Hope International (Seventh-day Adventist)|Hope International]] and [[Hartland Institute]] are expressions of historic Adventism."</ref><ref name="Hopeintreport"/>" [[Last Generation Theology]]" shares some elements with Historic Adventism, yet considers itself to have "expanded" the beliefs of Adventism to their logical conclusion.<ref>[http://progressiveadventism.com/2007/01/08/interlogue-4-larry-kirkpatrick/ Interview with Larry Kirkpatrick] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212071656/http://progressiveadventism.com/2007/01/08/interlogue-4-larry-kirkpatrick/ |date=2007-02-12 }} by [[Julius Nam]]</ref> Historic Adventists are seen as at the opposite end of the Adventist theological spectrum from [[Progressive Adventists]]. Prominent figures supporting some of the historic views include [[M. L. Andreasen]], and [[Standish brothers|Colin and Russell Standish]].
==History== {{See also|History of the Seventh-day Adventist Church}}
Teachings on Christian perfection and personal holiness were present in the religious revival of the [[Great Awakening]] in America and were evident in early Adventist movements such as the "[[Holy Flesh movement]]" in [[Indiana]] around the turn of the 19th century which Ellen White quickly rebuked."<ref>[http://sdadefend.com/Defend-foundation/counsel-Celebation.htm ''2nd Selected Messages'', p. 36-38., Ellen White]</ref> They were also evident in some teachings on holiness by medical doctor [[John Harvey Kellogg]], and [[Alonzo T. Jones|Jones]] and [[Ellet J. Waggoner|Waggoner]] of [[1888 Minneapolis General Conference|1888]] fame.<ref name="PatrickLater">{{cite web | last = Patrick | first = Arthur | authorlink = Arthur Patrick | title = Later Adventist Worship, Ellen White and the Holy Spirit: Further Historical Perspectives | work = Spiritual Discernment Conference | publisher = SDAnet AtIssue | date = c. 1999 | url = http://www.sdanet.org/atissue/discern/flesh.htm | doi = | accessdate = 2008-02-15 }}</ref>
[[Joseph Bates (Adventist)|Joseph Bates]] was one of the three primary founders of Seventh-day Adventism (along with James and Ellen White). Like many in the early church he focused more on following the requirements of God's law over salvation by grace.<ref>Benjamin McArthur, "Early Adventism's Leon Trotsky." ''Spectrum'' 33:2 (Spring 2005); [http://old.spectrummagazine.org/onlinecommunity/reviews/050706mcarthur.html alternative link] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100707113547/http://old.spectrummagazine.org/onlinecommunity/reviews/050706mcarthur.html |date=2010-07-07 }}<!-- Preferable will be a link to the new Spectrum website, when it becomes available perhaps c. 2015 -->. A review of [[George R. Knight]], ''Joseph Bates: The Real Founder of Seventh-day Adventism.'' Review and Herald, 2004</ref>
Following the [[1919 Bible Conference]], in which Ellen White's inspiration was discussed during two days, some defended against what they felt were attacks on her such as Holmes and Washburn, who wrote open letters decrying the alleged "new theology" and the "omega" apostasy of the Adventist church.<ref>http://www.sdanet.org/atissue/books/1919bc/hal-3.htm</ref>
[[Keith Lockhart (journalist)|Keith Lockhart]] has described the "[[Golden Age (metaphor)|Golden Age]]" of Adventism (from a sociological point of view) as the [[Fundamentalist Christianity|fundamentalist]] era of the 1920s–1950s. It is to this time period the expression "historic Adventism" most accurately applies, not to 19th century Adventism.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Diller |first=Lisa Clark |authorlink= |title=Bull's and Lockhart's Challenge to Adventist Progressives |url=http://adventist-forum.blogspot.com/2008/02/bulls-and-lockharts-challenge-to.html |journal=[[Adventist Today]] |volume=16 |issue=1 |pages= |publisher=Adventist Today Foundation |location=[[Loma Linda, California|Loma Linda]], [[California|CA]] |issn=1079-5499 |date=January 2008 |archiveurl=https://archive.is/20161022161225/http://adventist-forum.blogspot.nl/2008/02/bulls-and-lockharts-challenge-to.html |archivedate=2016-10-22 |accessdate=2016-10-22 |format=– <sup>[https://scholar.google.co.uk/scholar?hl=en&lr=&q=author%3A+intitle%3ABull%E2%80%99s+and+Lockhart%E2%80%99s+Challenge+to+Adventist+Progressives&as_publication=%5B%5BAdventist+Today%5D%5D&as_ylo=&as_yhi=&btnG=Search Scholar search]</sup> |deadurl=yes |df= }}</ref> Along with Malcolm Bull, he says "Adventist fundamentalism" emerged in the 1880s, became dominant in the 1920s, and survives to the present day among conservative groups." They also claim "elements of fundamentalism were re-invoked," becoming discernible in the 1990s.<ref>''[[Seeking a Sanctuary]],'' p104</ref> :"But what many authors take to be historic Adventism is in fact a creation of the twentieth century — a synthesis that took place in the 1920s and remained dominant until the 1960s. It was, moreover, a synthesis that in itself represented an accommodation to the newly formed fundamentalist movement."<ref>Bull and Lockhart, ''Seeking a Sanctuary,'' p90–91, as quoted elsewhere</ref>
===Adventist-Evangelical dialogues=== {{See also|Questions on Doctrine}} It is widely accepted that present historic Adventism emerged in response to the Adventist-Evangelical discussions that occurred in the spring of 1955 to the fall of 1957. These dialogues were initiated by evangelicals Donald Barnhouse and [[Walter Ralston Martin|Walter Martin]], who sought clarification on what Adventists believed and took issue with a number of teachings, which at the time were generally thought to characterize Adventist theology. The most significant of these being: [[Arianism|semi-arian]] views on the GodHead; man's sinful nature taken by Christ in His incarnation; an incomplete atonement at the time of Christ's death on the cross; salvation by obedience to the law; and extreme sectarianism.<ref name="samplesCRI"/> At least one author considers the various streams existed earlier, as some Millerites came from churches holding Arian views, but this event polarized them.<ref>Lowell Tarling claims this</ref>
The Adventist leaders who met with Walter Martin presented a fuller description of mainstream Adventist theology, and described the more fundamentalist views as merely the beliefs of a few. (Le Roy Edwin Froom described them as the "lunatic fringe.") In addition to showing it had clearly moved from [[Arianism|semi-arian]] views on the GodHead, the Adventists asserted that the belief that Christ took Adam's sinful nature after the fall and an incomplete atonement were not part of mainstream Adventist doctrine. Adventist historian George Knight felt it was not a complete picture as it could be, because a majority of Adventists prior to 1950 had held to these teachings concerning the nature of Christ and the atonement.<ref>''Questions on Doctrine: annotated edition 2005''</ref>
Martin and Barnhouse were satisfied with the responses given by the Adventist delegation, and concluded that the Adventist church was a legitimate Christian body. Meanwhile, Adventist theologian [[M. L. Andreasen]], who was aware of these proceedings, openly opposed what he felt was a change concerning the nature of Christ and the atonement and represented the many Adventists who held that view. (Those Adventists who believed Christ had taken a fallen nature still believed that Jesus was sinless and committed no actual sins, but they held that it included propensity or desire to sin). Some of these Adventists continue to oppose the theological direction taken by the church leadership on these issues and the more fundamentalist elements are known today as "Historic Adventists."
[[Herbert Douglass]] has stated, :"most, if not all, of the so-called 'dissident' or 'independent' groups of the last 45 years are direct results of the explicit and implicit positions espoused by [''Questions on Doctrine''] on the atonement and the Incarnation."<ref>as quoted on http://qod.andrews.edu/index.html</ref>
According to historian [[George R. Knight|George Knight]], :"Official Adventism may have gained recognition as being Christian from the [[evangelicalism|evangelical]] world, but in the process a breach had been opened which has not healed in the last 50 years and may never heal."<ref>George Knight, 2003 annotated edition of ''Questions on Doctrine''</ref>
=== 1970s === [[Desmond Ford]] convinced [[Robert Brinsmead]] his views on perfectionism were incorrect in about 1970.<ref name="Land"/> Robert Brinsmead himself however denies that Ford convinced him to abandon perfectionism and further states that he abandoned perfectionism as a result of his intensive study of the issues of the Protestant Reformation, Martin Luther, and justification by faith.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.presenttruthmag.com/mailbox/A%20Dialogue%20with%20Bob.htm|title=A Dialogue with a Former Christian Believer|website=www.presenttruthmag.com|access-date=2017-10-15}}</ref> During the 1970s, what is now the ''[[Adventist Review]]'' carried articles by editor [[Kenneth H. Wood|Kenneth Wood]] and associate editor [[Herbert E. Douglass|Herbert Douglass]] rejecting ''Questions on Doctrine'' and arguing for a final perfect generation.<ref name="Land">"Righteousness by Faith" entry in ''Historical Dictionary of Seventh-day Adventists'' by [[Gary Land]]</ref>
The General Conference addressed this controversy over "righteousness by faith" by holding a conference in [[Palmdale, California|Palmdale]], [[California]] in 1976.<ref name="Land"/> Ford was the "center of attention," and the resulting document known as the "[http://www.adventistarchives.org/docs/RH/RH1976-22/index.djvu?djvuopts&page=4 Palmdale Statement]"{{DjVulink}}.<ref name="Shaking1">[http://www.presenttruthmag.com/7dayadventist/shaking/1.html Adventists: Heirs of the Reformation], chapter 1 of ''[http://www.presenttruthmag.com/7dayadventist/shaking/index.html The Shaking of Adventism]'' by Geoffrey J. Paxton</ref><ref>{{cite journal | last = | first = | authorlink = | coauthors = | title = Christ Our Righteousness | journal = [[Adventist Review]] | volume = 153 | issue = 22 | pages = 4–7 | publisher = [[Review and Herald Publishing Association|Review and Herald]] | location = [[Washington, D.C.]] | issn = 0161-1119 | date = | url = http://www.adventistarchives.org/docs/RH/RH1976-22/index.djvu?djvuopts&page=4 | format = [[DjVu]] | doi = | id = | accessdate = 2007-10-23 }}</ref> However the controversy continued and critics of the "new theology" of Ford and others formed institutions to respond them.<ref name="Land"/>
[[Julius Nam]] has written, :"However, the theological heirs of Andreasen have found such developments deeply troubling. Since 1971, several independent ministry groups have arisen within the Adventist church that have self-consciously embraced Andreasen's [[postlapsarian]] views and the accompanying theology of the final generation, which they believe is supported by the writings of Ellen White. Since their inception, these groups have warned against the evangelicalization of Adventism and have issued calls to the church at large to return to the Adventism of the pre-''Questions on Doctrine'' era. Like Andreasen, they have seen the Adventist-evangelical conferences and the publication of ''Questions on Doctrine'' as the beginning of the end-time apostasy. From the perspective of these groups, the prelapsarian view advocated by ''Questions on Doctrine'' and embraced by many Adventists is another sign of the apostasy that continues in the church. They view Adventism as a movement that is to be deliberately separate from other groups such as evangelicals. Their vision of Adventism is a movement that is preparing the final generation of Christians who will ultimately overcome sin."<ref>{{cite web |title=The Questions on Doctrine Saga: Contours and Lessons |author=Julius Nam |url=http://progressiveadventism.com/2007/11/02/the-questions-on-doctrine-saga-contours-and-lessons/ |publisher=Paper presented to ''QOD'' 50th anniversary conference |year=2007 }}</ref>
The 1975 book ''Perfection: The Impossible Possibility'' ([[Nashville, Tennessee|Nashville]]: [[Southern Publishing Association]], 1975) edited by Douglass, contained essays by Douglass and C. Mervyn Maxwell supporting traditional Adventist views, and [[Edward Heppenstall]] and [[Hans LaRondelle]] supporting their view.
==Theology== Historic Adventist theology tends to differ from mainstream Adventist theology in the areas of [[Christology]], [[hamartiology]] (sin), [[soteriology]] (salvation) and [[eschatology]] (end times). They often use the term "new theology" as a pejorative term for perceived doctrinal shifts in the church.<ref>e.g. {{cite book|author=Colin D. Standish and Russell R. Standish|title=Deceptions of the New Theology|publisher=Hartland Publications|year=1989|isbn=978-0-923309-18-3}}</ref>
With regards to Christology, according to Adventist historian George Knight, most early Adventists believed that Jesus Christ was born with a human nature that was not only physically frail and subject to temptation, but that he also had the fallen predisposition and inclination to sin.<ref>Questions on Doctrine, annotated edition, 2005.</ref> Since 1950, the "historic" wing of the church continues to hold this "fallen" view of Christ's human nature, though it is now a minority position among theologians and mainstream Adventism.<ref>{{cite book |title=Questions on Doctrine, annotated edition (2003) |publisher=Andrews University Press |pages=516–526 }}</ref>
Historic Adventists, like mainstream Adventists, believe that [[sin]] is defined in terms of personal transgressions of the commandments, over against an inborn corruption of the human nature inherited from Adam.<ref name="WhiddenQod"/><ref>{{Cite journal|author=Gerhard Pfandl|title=Some Thoughts on Original Sin|publisher=[[Biblical Research Institute]], General Conference of Seventh-day Adventists|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref>
Historic Adventists tend to place more emphasis on [[sanctification]] than [[justification (theology)|justification]].<ref name="WhiddenQod">{{Cite journal|author=Woodrow Whidden|title=Question On Doctrine: What Should Be the Enduring Theological Legacy?|year=2007|postscript=<!-- Bot inserted parameter. Either remove it; or change its value to "." for the cite to end in a ".", as necessary. -->{{inconsistent citations}}}}</ref> Following Andreasen, they define the [[Atonement in Christianity|atonement]] in terms of God's work to cleanse our character from sin as well as payment of the penalty for sin. The work of Christ in the heavenly sanctuary is regarded as a continuation of the work of atonement begun on the cross, rather than the application of the benefits of an already completed atonement. <ref>{{cite book |title=Questions on Doctrine, annotated edition (2003) |publisher=Andrews University Press |pages=xix-xxi }}</ref>
"Eschatological perfectionism" is the teaching that a final generation of believers must achieve a state of perfection or complete sinlessness in the final period just before the [[second coming]] of Jesus (see [[Last Generation Theology]]) and most Historic Adventists hold to that teaching. This belief in sinlessness arose particularly from [[M. L. Andreasen]]'s interpretation of the [[investigative judgment]] doctrine, which is one of the pillars of Adventism and found in [[The Great Controversy (book)|''The Great Controversy'']] by [[Ellen G. White]].<ref name="samplesCRI">{{cite web|author=Kenneth Samples|title=From Controversy to Crisis: An Updated Assessment of Seventh-day Adventism|publisher=Christian Research Institute|url=http://www.iclnet.org/pub/resources/text/cri/cri-jrnl/web/crj0005b.html}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|author=[[Anthony A. Hoekema]]|title=The Four Major Cults|year=1962|publisher=Eerdmans|pages=124, see also note 127}}</ref>
Historic Adventists generally place more emphasis on the writings of Ellen G. White as a doctrinal authority compared to mainstream Adventists, some considering her writings as [[Biblical infallibility|infallible]] and having near-equivalent status to the [[Bible]].<ref name="Corson"/>
Historic Adventists have a differing perspective on the [[1888 Minneapolis General Conference]] arguing that Ellen White in addition to have supported Jones and Waggoner, but also perfectionistic theology, which some say came from them.<ref name="Whidden">{{cite web | author=Whidden, Woodrow | title=Ellen White on the Humanity of Christ (chapter 10) | url=http://www.sdanet.org/atissue/books/wwhc/hoc10.htm | publisher=Review and Herald Publishing Association |year=1997}}</ref>
Some historic Adventists, like many mainstream Adventists, are advocates of the [[King James Only movement]], which promotes sole use of the [[Authorized King James Version|King James Version]] of the Bible. (A classic book in this movement, ''[[Our Authorized Bible Vindicated]]'' (1930), was written by an Adventist, [[Benjamin G. Wilkinson]]. One critique is by [[Alden Thompson]].<ref>Alden Thompson, [http://www.wallawalla.edu/fileadmin/user_upload/theology/Alden_Thompson/Writings/Unpublished_Papers/B.G._Wilkinson_s_Our_Authorized_Bible_Vindicated_-_a_Critique.rtf critique] ([[Rich Text Format|RTF]]). March 24, 1995</ref>)
=== Last Generation Theology === {{Main article|Last Generation Theology}} '''Last Generation Theology''' (LGT) or "'''final generation'''" '''theology''' is a belief system held by some conservative members of the [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]], which claims that [[Christian perfection|perfection]] like the [[144,000]] will be achieved by some people in the last generation before the [[Second Coming]] of [[Jesus]]. It is closely related to "historic Adventism," but as one supporter claims, it differs in that it forms an extension or development of traditional Adventist beliefs, or takes them to their logical conclusion.
==Criticism== Mainstream and [[progressive Adventists]] have criticised the use of the term "historic." It is observed that numerous doctrinal positions that were common among the Adventist pioneers are generally not held by those who profess to be "historic Adventists," such as semi-[[Arianism]], what time of day the Sabbath should begin, certain understandings of Systematic Benevolence, the "shut door," and the personhood of the Holy Spirit.<ref name="Whidden"/> It is argued that the over-valuing of "historic" beliefs leads to an unhelpful neglect of "new light" and "present truth," which Adventists have always held as defining beliefs.
[[Walter Ralston Martin|Walter Martin]] labeled most of the historic Adventists he encountered as "legalists," "worshippers of Ellen White" and the "lunatic fringe."<ref>Walter Martin Interview, ''[[Adventist Currents]]'', Vol. 1, No. 1, July, 1983, conducted by Douglas Hackleman.</ref> The term was earlier used by [[LeRoy Edwin Froom]] when Adventist leaders met with Martin.<ref>[http://www.iclnet.org/pub/resources/text/cri/cri-jrnl/web/crj0005b.html CRI Journal - CRJ0005B<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref>
Adventist historian [[Milton Hook]] describes it as "Adventist fundamentalism." He cites the aggressive preaching style of George Burnside who attacked Roman Catholics and "apostate" Protestants. Hook says this turned many away, and some of the remaining merely "loved a religious dogfight," and converts "often generated dust storms of intolerance and became clones of militant dogmatism among their peers." He states this style of evangelism was once the norm among Adventist preachers, and had roots in 19th century Methodism in the United States.<ref>{{cite book | last = Hook | first = Milton | authorlink = | title = Desmond Ford: Reformist Theologian, Gospel Revivalist | publisher = [[Adventist Today]] | year = 2008 | location = Riverside, California | pages = 40–41 | url = | isbn = 0-9786141-9-4 }} [http://atoday.com/content/desmond-ford-reformist-theologian-gospel-revivalist-paperback Publisher's page] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090907021215/http://atoday.com/content/desmond-ford-reformist-theologian-gospel-revivalist-paperback |date=2009-09-07 }}. See also other parts of the chapter and book</ref>
Andy Nash wrote that while working at the ''Adventist Review,'' he was "often perplexed about how our ability to function at the magazine was disrupted by some folk on the conservative extreme." In response to articles on worship, they would get many critical letters that were based more on tradition than on the Bible. They would airbrush jewelry out of photos to placate some readers.<ref>Andy Nash, "[http://www.adventistreview.org/issue.php?issue=2010-1511&page=18 Meet @ the Text: The Case for a Strong Adventist Center] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100917183844/http://adventistreview.org/issue.php?issue=2010-1511&page=18 |date=2010-09-17 }}." ''Adventist Review'' 187 (April 15, 2010), p18–21. Article featured on magazine cover</ref>
Historic Adventists look favorably on a past era of the church. Phil Dunham, a fairly conservative author himself, critiqued "nostalgia about the good old days of 'historic Adventism.' In some people's minds it seems to be a time of the most unblemished and unassailable doctrinal positions, the highest possible moral standards, the deepest spiritual maturity, the best snowlike purity, the utmost in readiness to be translated.[…] But the way we often use the expression 'historic Seventh-day Adventism' is built on an idealized and unrealistic notion of what our early church was really like."<ref>Philip W. Dunham with Maylan Schurch, ''Blinded by the Light: The Anatomy of Apostasy.'' Hagerstown, MD: Review and Herald, 2001, p93–94</ref> :"These days a lot of well-meaning people yearn for the supposedly purer days of the past. They feel that if they could just retrieve historic Seventh-day Adventism and bathe in its supposedly clearer waters, they'd be better able to resist last-day influences. :'Back then,' they assert, 'people had a higher level of spirituality — and a lower rate of problems. Back then apostasy was somehow banned, or at least kept at bay.' :Not true. Not true for historic Seventh-day Adventism. Not true for the historic church of Christ — the New Testament church. Not true for the seventh-day church in the wilderness—historic [[Judaism]]. Not true even for the First Church of Eden, because its entire two-member congregation ran and hid in naked apostasy. :No, you can't just change your group's name, or meet in a Grange Hall someplace, to escape apostasy. The seeds of apostasy grow not in a name or a place or a time — but in the hearts of every person on this planet since Adam and Eve.[…]"<ref>Dunham, p67</ref>
[[File:YellowChurchBillboard.jpg|thumb|right|Historic Adventist roadside [[Billboard (advertising)|billboard]]. Text reads, ''"SATURDAY the True Lord's Day Changed by Antichrist <small>{{bibleverse||Dan.|7:25|KJV}}</small>'']]
===Responses to criticism=== In response, some historic Adventists have claimed that they are loving in their evangelism and deny that the charge of fanaticism applies to them. They quote statements by Ellen White to support their view. For instance:
: "Men will misrepresent the doctrines we believe and teach as Bible truth, and it is necessary that wise plans should be laid to secure the privilege of inserting articles into the secular papers; for this will be a means of awakening souls to see the truth. God will raise up men who will be qualified to sow beside all waters. God has given great light upon important truths, and it must come to the world."<ref>Ellen G. White, Letter 1, 1875.</ref>
: "We must take every justifiable means of bringing the light before the people. Let the press be utilized, and let every advertising agency be employed that will call attention to the work. This should not be regarded as nonessential. On every street corner you may see placards and notices calling attention to various things that are going on, some of them of the most objectionable character; and shall those who have the light of life be satisfied with feeble efforts to call the attention of the masses to the truth?"<ref>Ellen G. White, Evangelism, p. 130.</ref>
Methodist scholar [[Donald Dayton]] expressed some sympathies for historic Adventists in his paper presented at the [[Questions on Doctrine#50th anniversary conference|''Questions on Doctrine'' 50th anniversary conference]].<ref>"[http://qod.andrews.edu/docs/10_donald_dayton.pdf Some Reflections on Adventist Identity by a 'Sympathetic Outsider' on the Fiftieth Anniversary of the Publication of ''Questions on Doctrine'']" by Donald Dayton. ''Questions on Doctrine'' 50th anniversary conference, 2007. Accessed 2008-04-16</ref>
==Official church reaction== The [[Seventh-day Adventist Church]] has officially reacted to two organizations that some say have "historic Adventist" theology, Hope International, and the Hartland Institute (USA) and [[Remnant Ministries]] (Australia). In 1998, the [[General Conference of Seventh-day Adventists|General Conference]] established a committee to evaluate the beliefs and activities and the committee produced a report expressing "serious concerns with respect to the nature and purpose of Hope International and associates."<ref name="Hopeintreport">[http://www.adventistreview.org/2000-1538/hope-international.html Report on Hope International and Associated Groups] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060512182701/http://www.adventistreview.org/2000-1538/hope-international.html |date=2006-05-12 }}, Adventist Review, 2000.</ref>
The conclusion of the report stated that "by rejecting the authority of the [[General Conference Session|world church in session]] when their interpretation of Scripture and the Spirit of Prophecy differs from that of the church, Hope International and associates have set their authority above that of the world church and operate in a manner that is consistent with offshoot movements." The report also contained a significant escalation: "If Hope International and associates cannot bring themselves into harmony with the body of the world church, clearly evidenced within 12 months, the Seventh-day Adventist Church may need to consider whether there exists a "persistent refusal to recognize properly constituted church authority or to submit to the order and discipline of the church" (Church Manual, p. 169)."<ref name="Hopeintreport"/>
According to one article, the policy of the [[North American Division of Seventh-day Adventists|Adventist church in North America]] is that members of Hartland or Hope International may not hold any church office.<ref>"[http://www.atoday.com/magazine/1998/07/living-remnant-0 Living with the Remnant]" by Debra Lloyd Foote. ''Adventist Today'' [http://www.atoday.com/magazine/1998/07 6:4]</ref>
==Organizations and people==
===Para-church ministries=== In addition to Hope International (Seventh-day Adventist), and the [[Hartland Institute]],<ref>''Seeking a Sanctuary''</ref> there are a number of para-church organizations that assist in the articulation and defense of the Historic Adventists' views. Hope International, formerly led by Ron Spear, runs a publishing ministry and a health center. Hartland Institute comprises an educational college and health center associated with Colin Standish (who founded the organization ). It publishes their books and others, as well as ''Last Generation'' magazine.<ref name="Hartland">"Hartland Institute of Health and Education" in ''Historical Dictionary of Seventh-day Adventists'' by [[Gary Land]]. See [http://www.hartland.edu/ Hartland College, Lifestyle Center, Publications and Natural Farm website]</ref>
'''Remnant Ministries''' was founded by Russell Standish<ref name="QOD">[http://qod.andrews.edu/presenters.html Presenters at the ''Questions on Doctrine'' 50th Anniversary Conference]</ref> and is based in Australia.<ref>[http://www.adventistreview.org/2000-1538/hope-international.html Adventist Review: Hope International<!-- Bot generated title -->] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20060512182701/http://www.adventistreview.org/2000-1538/hope-international.html |date=2006-05-12 }}</ref>
==== Concerned Brethren ==== <!-- Image with inadequate rationale removed: [[File:SundayLawTimes01.JPG|thumb|200px|left|''The Sunday Law Times'' is published by an Australasia Historic Adventist movement. It warns of a [[New World Order]] under the United States and Papacy, which will enforce a universal Sunday law.]] -->
The term "Concerned Brethren" describes an Adventist movement in [[Australasia]]<ref>"[http://www.greatcontroversy.org/documents/papers/cmm-4hun.html Hope International and Associates—Another Perspective]" by C. Mervyn Maxwell (previously known as the "Four Legitimate Hungers" Letter)</ref> (not to be confused with the [[Plymouth Brethren|Brethren]] churches, a Christian movement entirely separate from Adventism). The description was used of a group of retired ministers opposed to [[Desmond Ford]]'s teachings, particularly during his time as head of theology at [[Avondale College]], and who urged for his dismissal.<ref name="Sep">''The Sepulchers Are Whited'' by the Standish brothers, p1, 142</ref> The name derived from their signature or self-designation on a letter in the 1970s,{{Citation needed|date=January 2008}} although the stream of thought had been discernible earlier.<ref>[http://www.sdanet.org/atissue/doctrines/qod2007conf/patrick-qod-impact.htm Patrick, 2007 QOD Conference Paper</span><!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> According to E. Bruce Price, "'Concerned Brethren' was abbreviated to 'CB' as a term of derision for those opposing Dr. Ford's new theology."<ref name="Sep"/><ref name="Price">"[http://www.biblicalperspectives.com/endtimeissues/et_130.htm Church Growth Experiments in Secular Australia]" by E. Bruce Price in ''Here We Stand: Evaluating New Trends in the Church'' edited by [[Samuel Koranteng-Pipim]]. [[Berrien Springs, Michigan|Berrien Springs]], [[Michigan]]: ''[[Adventists Affirm]],'' 2005. {{ISBN|0-9677622-1-9}} ([http://www.adventistsaffirm.org/transaction_detail.php?id=1 publisher's page]). Chapter republished in [[Samuele Bacchiocchi]]'s ''Endtime Issues Newsletter'' No. 130</ref> According to the Standishes, "Hope International is to the [[United States]] what the Gazeley meetings are to [[United Kingdom|Britain]], and the Concerned Brethren are to [[Australia]] and [[New Zealand]]."<ref name="Sep"/>
The group was led<ref name="Shaking7">"[http://www.presenttruthmag.com/7dayadventist/shaking/7.html Advance and Retreat: The 1970s]" chapter in ''The Shaking of Adventism''</ref> by James William Kent (1890 – May 5, 1983, Australia, aged 93), a "veteran Australian evangelist and administrator,"<ref>''Adventist Review'' [http://www.adventistarchives.org/docs/RH/RH19830609-V160-23/index.djvu?djvuopts&page=24 June 9, 1983], p24. See [http://jewel.andrews.edu:82/search/a?Kent+J+W articles by Kent] cataloged in the Seventh-day Adventist Periodical Index (SDAPI). The Standishes (who have a "historic" point of view) call Kent, "in our judgment the greatest Seventh-day Adventist orator we have ever heard."</ref><ref>Birthdate from ''The Greatest of All the Prophets,'' p379<!-- The Standishes are incorrect about Kent's middle name, according to Kent's grandson whom I asked personally. Need to reference this properly. -CM --></ref> who chaired a meeting of "concerned" individuals in [[Sydney]] in 1974.<ref>''The Gathering Storm and the Storm Burst,'' 77</ref> On 3–4 February 1976, a group of 16 men (11 "senior ministers," all retired, and five laymen) including Kent and George Burnside (1908–1994), a New Zealand evangelist<ref name="Price"/><ref>Stanley Wood, "A[ustralian] M[issionary] College Notes." ''Australasian Record'' (April 24, 1933), p3. A[lbert] Mitchell, "Wedding Bells." ''Australasian Record'' (March 2, 1936), p7. Bruce Manners, "Burnside: A Life of Evangelism." ''Australasian Record'' (April 30, 1994), p10. Above as cited by Hook, p65 footnote 6. Loma Linda University Library has a file on Burnside (see [http://lluweb2.llu.edu/heritage/SDABiographyFileSearch.asp here]). See also [http://jewel.andrews.edu:82/search/a?Burnside+George articles by Burnside] cataloged in the Seventh-day Adventist Periodical Index. Full name and lifespan from ''The Greatest of All the Prophets,'' p139. Burnside was converted by Kent. See also his mention in the [[Longburn Adventist College]] centenary book</ref> (described as the "foremost anti-Ford pamphleteer")<ref>Tarling, 204</ref> was given a hearing by 20 men from the [[Biblical Research Institute]] in the Australasian Division (now the [[South Pacific Division of Seventh-day Adventists|South Pacific Division]]).<ref>All names are recorded in ''The Greatest of All the Prophets,'' 384–86</ref> According to one author, Ford's understanding of righteousness by faith was the main issue,<ref name="Shaking7"/> while the report describes "concern about the teaching of theology at Avondale College, particularly in the area of the [[Heavenly Sanctuary|Sanctuary]], the [[Age of the Earth]], and Inspiration."<ref name="report">Notice of the action of the Australasian Division of the Biblical Research Institute. As reproduced in ''The Greatest of All the Prophets'' by the Standish brothers, p384</ref> In response, the Institute affirmed its support for Avondale in its report.<ref name="report"/>
In March 1977, Kent and others met with Ford and church administrators. They were informed this would be the last time they could meet with church leaders as a group.<ref>''Adventism Challenged'' by the Standishes, p280, as quoted on a website</ref> Kent and Burnside were banned from preaching in the churches on December 18, 1978, because of their continued opposition to Ford.<ref name="Price"/> A. C. Needham replaced Kent as unofficial leader around this time, as the latter approached his 90th birthday.<ref>''The Gathering Storm and the Storm Burst,'' 86</ref>
According to Arthur Patrick, "Looking back on the painful saga of the 'Concerned Brethren' from 1974 to the present, it is apparent that a better application of essentials for effective pastoral care may have alleviated some of the controversy."<ref>"[http://www.sdanet.org/atissue/white/patrick/egw-retrospect.htm Ellen White and South Pacific Adventism: Retrospect and Prospect]" by Arthur Patrick</ref> Also, "Following the conflicts that gained intensity in the 1950s, during the 1970s the Adventist Church in Australasia made significant progress in better understanding and presenting 'the everlasting gospel;' but it failed to win the support of certain older members. In addition, viewpoints similar to those of the Concerned Brethren were promulgated by a variety of independent groups."<ref>[http://www.atoday.com/magazine/2005/11/twenty-five-years-after-glacier-view Twenty-Five Years After Glacier View | Adventist Today<!-- Bot generated title -->]</ref> He has described them as "loyalists."
==== Adventist Laymen's Fellowship ==== The Adventist Laymen's Fellowship (ALF) was founded in 1979 to counter the growing Desmond Ford movement in Australia. They held a series of weekend meetings at Vision Valley, outside Sydney, to which local and overseas conservative Adventist speakers were invited and to which several thousand Adventists attended over several years. Early speakers included Colin Standish, Ralph Larson, George Burnside, Austin Cooke, Mervyn Maxwell, Leroy Moore, Dennis Priebe and others. They also published a magazine for several years named ''Landmarks.'' The ALF succumbed to theological unorthodoxy and disbanded about 1986.{{Citation needed|reason=Reliable source needed for the whole sentence|date=September 2009}}
===Publishing=== Historic Adventists have a strong commitment to publishing, and often disseminate free literature to promote their views to the mainstream church and wider public.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cgm.org.au/ |title= Concerned Christians Growth Ministries Inc. }}</ref>
* ''[[Our Firm Foundation]]''<ref>"Hope International" in ''Historical Dictionary of Seventh-day Adventists'' by [[Gary Land]], p.137–38</ref> is a monthly magazine published by Hope International. [[Alden Thompson]] has described it as "the theological heir to the perfectionism of the 'old' ''[[Adventist Review]]'' (era of [[Kenneth H. Wood|Kenneth Wood]]), though its strident criticism of mainstream Adventism has alienated many who would share its theological perspective."<ref name="Thompson">{{cite web |last=Thompson |first=Alden |authorlink=Alden Thompson |title=The Future of Adventism: Where's The Church Headed? |work=AldenThompson.com |publisher= |date= |url=http://people.wwc.edu/staff/thomal/unpub/futur_adventism.htm |doi= |accessdate=2007-10-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20070927215340/http://people.wwc.edu/staff/thomal/unpub/futur_adventism.htm |archivedate=2007-09-27 |df= }}</ref> The Standishes consider it "the finest English language message paper in the entire denomination."<ref name="Sep"/> * ''Anchor'' is a historic Adventist magazine which was first published in April 1985. It was first edited by H. H. Meyers, and later by Ron and Ula Cable; published from [[Queensland]], Australia.<ref>''The Evangelical Dilemma'' by Colin Standish, Russell Standish, and H. H. Meyers, p79</ref> * ''Pilgrim's Rest'' or ''Waymarks'' are [[Self-publishing|self-published]] by Vance Ferrell. Alden Thompson describes the publication as "A strident 'Adventist' voice (Vance Ferrell), literally from the wilderness (of Tennessee). Pilgrim's Rest has been active in stirring up traditional elements in Adventist {{sic}} against the 'compromising' mainstream Adventist institutions, especially the General Conference and Adventist colleges."<ref name="Thompson"/><ref>"[http://www.atoday.com/magazine/1996/05/walla-walla-college-criticized-0 Walla Walla College Criticized]" in ''[[Adventist Today]]'' comments on the publication</ref> Ferrell also set up [http://sdadefend.com/ SDADefend.com] and [http://ellenwhitedefend.com/ EllenWhiteDefend.com].<ref>''[[Seeking a Sanctuary]]'', 342</ref> * ''Quo Vadis'' ([http://www.dougplata.com/religion/qv/ archives]) is a magazine edited by Kevin Paulson. The title is taken from [[Quo vadis|the Latin expression]].
===Other notable historic Adventist people=== * [[M. L. Andreasen]] — author of ''The Sanctuary Service'' ([[Review and Herald Publishing Association|Review and Herald]], 1947), and credited with developing [[Last Generation Theology]]. * [[Ralph Larson]]<ref>"[http://www.atoday.com/magazine/1994/01/historic-adventism-remembering-trust-and-obey Historic Adventism: Remembering to Trust and Obey]" by Ralph Larson. ''[[Adventist Today]]'' [http://www.atoday.com/magazine/1994/01 '''2''':1 (January 1994)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070823053321/http://www.atoday.com/magazine/1994/01 |date=2007-08-23 }}</ref> * Larry Kirkpatrick is a pastor who runs the "anti-liberal" historic website [http://greatcontroversy.org/ GreatControversy.org]<ref>''Seeking a Sanctuary'', probably p342. See also the [http://progressiveadventism.com/2007/01/08/interlogue-4-larry-kirkpatrick/ interview] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070212071656/http://progressiveadventism.com/2007/01/08/interlogue-4-larry-kirkpatrick/ |date=2007-02-12 }} with [[Julius Nam]]</ref> * Col Martens, of Steps to Life ([https://www.steps.org.au/ website]) in Australia
===Former historic Adventists===
====Transition to non-Adventist==== * Australian [[Robert Brinsmead]] promoted the "Awakening Movement" in the 1960s before transitioning to a strong evangelical Adventist focus, and then later rejecting many Adventist and orthodox Christian beliefs.<ref name="Land-a">"BRINSMEAD, ROBERT DAVID (1933- )" in [[Gary Land]], ''Historical Dictionary of Seventh-day Adventists'', p.47</ref><ref name="Pahl">[http://www.atoday.com/magazine/1999/05/where-robert-brinsmead Where is Robert Brinsmead?] by Larry Pahl; ''[[Adventist Today]]'' [http://www.atoday.com/magazine/1999/05 7:3 (May/June 1999)]</ref>
====Transition to standard Adventism==== * [[George R. Knight]] was once a perfectionist.<ref>''I Used to Be Perfect: A Study of Sin and Salvation'' by George Knight</ref>
====Transition to progressive Adventism==== * Woodrow W. Whidden II, who has described himself as "a self-confessed former post-Fall perfectionist".<ref>http://www.sdanet.org/atissue/books/wwhc/hoc10.htm (p. 79)</ref> See his [http://progressiveadventism.com/2007/02/16/interlogue-18-woodrow-whidden interview] by [[Julius Nam]], in which he describes historic Adventists and his relationship with them.
